author: velact93
title: Mental Health support in Boston
body:
Poor Mental Health Service.  
Or... "Basically if you have a mental health issue, go private or get help from a charity if you can."  
I am writing both about my individual experience as a mental health patient and the treatment I witnessed of other patients.  
As a disclaimer overall I agree with affordable health care in principle and I am grateful for the support of people in the NHS. I going to rant in this post because it needs to be said I hope that it wakes some executive up at the Pilgrim, a politician perhaps or someone who has the ability to change the system.  
Mental Health Support in Boston, Lincolnshire from the Pilgrim and the area in general even just pre-pandemic ranges in my experience from detrimental to nothing.  
I have been let down by the Lincolnshire Trust, the bureaucracy and being passed on from service to service. Even whilst in distress I have tried to be civil, reasonable, treat the professionals with respect and be articulate. Reading between the lines it just seems like as a patient, care for my mental health is not a priority. I have issues with how mental health services in Lincolnshire are ran.  
Writing this I am probable going to get a standard response about contacting PALS that a Twitter bot could have written. I am tired, I am angry and I wanted help the NHS mental health services failed me. I was shocked at the level of prejudice, discrimination seen towards other patients and staff.  
Medical records lost, information with held, promises of family support non existent. The Crisis Team in Boston is not fit for purpose. I know that as a fact many patients in the Boston area are told to telephone the crisis team (CRHT) or get help from the CMHT but those patients do not use the service because we feel it is not fit for purpose.  
It is as if you have to say certain magic words to get the help you need perhaps this is because there is a massive difference in what there is in reality and the NICE guidelines suggest.  
Getting supportive treatment is difficult to impossible for people who are classed as high functioning and patients seem to be off rolled. The figures, statistics and the ratings matter but they are not a good indicator of how the service is. It feels like the patient does not come first. Lincolnshire has a single point of access but I was basically just fobbed off bounced back from CBT to CMHT.  
CBT is massively promoted, it has long waiting times and the treatment times are short plus with large class sizes the quality is poor. As I did not respond well to CBT, I was off rolled back to your GP after one to two weeks. CBT is provided by steps to change and they off rolled me of the course, I am not allowed to access any help because I am not allowed to compete steps to changes basic course.  
Getting access to Mental Health care in Lincolnshire has been difficult if not impossible and the system doesn't make any sense. I have been told to talk about mental health and get some support but when I do I get told to effectively shut up.  
I know that I suffer with depression, I suffer with anxiety, PTSD, I have been stabbed, burned, raped, been threatened with firearms, I have lost count of the amount of times people have attempted to murder me, I have been homeless, I have seen people suffer and die. I have tried to keep going and live a good life. I have tried to get an education, I have worked when I can, I have earned qualification, I have volunteered but I needed some at certain from the NHS but it just was not there.  
People tell me you can talk about mental health but that is a lie, you have to keep it a secret because you will probably lose your job and people will not consider you for opportunities.  
Mental Health support in Boston, at Pilgrim the reality is there has been none for me. I battle every day to be kind and not hurt those who have hurt me but I think about revenge everyday. I know this is because my mental health is poor but I do not talk about it openly anymore with mental health professionals everyday I have to make a choice not to seek revenge.  
I know the PHQ-9 test by memory. I hide my scars, hide the shaking from the PTSD, the vomit from the anxiety (I always have a toothbrush on me), I live alone no one sees me scream at night, I use ice packs for the pain, I use a gun shield at night for when the flashbacks happen. I am in agony, I want some relief and I would not say I have given up with the NHS but I would say that I have accepted that there is no help for me on the NHS but there is a lot of rubbish that says there is help but again the reality is there is nothing.  
I have seen patients be told if you want help you will have to have a proper suicide attempt. To use an analogy I feel like I am treated like Frankenstein's creature or the Gollum of Folklore, you had your use, your not wanted but worse your a mental health monster.  
If you want to improve the NHS mental services set up some real practical help and support services. Stop cutting effective services and passing them off as improvements. The NHS should cut down on false promises and the marketing hype. How can we as patients be expected to integrate into society if realistically there is no support?  
Maybe this comment will be removed but I have been silent for long enough and I want to exercise my freedom of speech. Perhaps reading this things might change but honestly I do not think they ever will.  
I have no trust in the CRHT, the CMHT and mental health services. If someone who has a friend or family member who is suffering I would suggest private care and support if possible or even support from a charity. Mental Health is a broken system sold as everything is fine like a dead parrot sketch. As for the loving acronyms there is one I would use to describe the service as B.S but that does not mean Brilliant Service (use your imagination). I have come to the conclusion that there is no help for someone like me. I genuinely hope that sometime in the next few years I go to sleep unaware and die. When I needed support there was none, I am in agony and I just want it to end.

author: ian 29
title: My son is in neuro
body: I feel that as a family how can the hospital say we can't contact him only well 1 person but in this case 2. I am His dad an I can't even video call him, as you say we don't have consent. How can this be? I can bet there are loads in this situation

readBy.name: Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: julyrc63
title: Hysteroscopy
body: It was done without anaesthetic. It was excruciatingly painful. I was not made aware of my options beforehand. I was left feeling traumatised, shocked. I felt violated.

author: DDB1
title: Orthopaedic Care
body:
8 months ago I had surgery on both my arms and needed to stay in hospital overnight to get my pain under control. The experience was fine for the most part and the staff were great in the lead up to the surgery and the morning before the surgery.  
After the surgery I needed assistance to go to the bathroom due to both arms being operated on and unfortunately I did not have a good experience with this. The first time I needed the toilet after surgery I was left on a commode for about 20 minutes without any way of getting assistance without shouting. Again in the morning I was left needing the bathroom for over 2 hours. I asked 2 nurses each, about half an hour apart, who said they would come back to me once they had finished their quick task. When neither of them returned I pushed my assistance button and asked a third staff member who said they would go and get the nurses. I ended up pacing near my bed and had resigned myself to just go stand over the toilet so that I didn't end up wetting myself on the floor. Eventually the cleaner saw me distressed and managed to go and get one of the morning staff to come and help me. The night staff at no point apologised and just walked past me later to go home.  
This was a particularly embarrassing situation for me made worse by how it was handled. I am a young woman and being put in the position where I had asked for help multiple times and was left feeling like I was going to have to be incontinent was very upsetting. I work in a hospital and I understand that people are busy however I do not feel that this was ok.

author: maxal
title: Great phlebotomy service
body:
Had a lovely visit from a nurse named Kim who works for North Lanarkshire Health board phlebotomy service. Very quick, efficient and a lovely manner!  
Great service :)

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: MShellem
title: Good support
body:
So far the meetings have helped me to get engaged.
I have had good support from my case worker, Simon.
It was nice to see becky.
I have only just started, but the group seems to have a good connection and I can see support networks forming.

author: perseusbk83
title: Thank you staff
body: Whilst ive been on lock down in this covid 19 I have received daily checks from staff members of St. Helens cgl to check on my wellbeing as I suffer with cops they have made it available for me to access zoom groups on 6 days a week. Going through this troubled time an me suffering anxiety I don't know where i'd of been without st. helens cgl staff at cgl st. helen are to me classed as friends not key workers. Thank you st. helens cgl‚ù§

author: lena was bolton
title: The service has changed my life
body:
I‚Äôve been in treatment nearly 30yrs. This service changed my life from me walking through their doors in December 2018. I‚Äôm living proof that we can all change grow and live, this service has helped me massively I arrived in what I stood in in a strange town on my own, cgl has changed my life, now I‚Äôm a service user rep, naloxone peer educator living in my own flat living drug free, during my time I‚Äôve been encouraged in every area from housing, benefits, accessing other services to rebuild my life, and maintain my recovery. I am truly grateful to my keyworker Martine, Amanda and manager Rachel for always encouraging me to carry on also all the other staff,  
During Covid 19 cgl have gone above and beyond to make sure we are all supported and know that there for us  
Truly grateful

author: Gilzo
title: Medical notes
body: Was admitted to hospital in July 2017 after taking an overdose. After a week and a half got sent to Leicester Glenfield hospital for ECMO then after about a month got sent back to ninewells to recover. I think that there are some gaps in my medical notes that are missing from my time in hospital, and don't know who can help with this.

author: Teric
title: Thorough investigation
body: Very thorough investigation of suspected DVT, further appointment issued to attend on Tuesday

author: Aunia
title: My recent A&E visit
body: I cannot thank the Medway Maritime A&E enough for the fantastic treatment I received. I was treated with respect in a very professional manner and was immediately put at ease by these wonderful people. They work under very difficult circumstances and give their very best. Bravo to all you wonderful angels.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Emmrd63
title: Very helpful
body:
My thanks to Cal in the IMCA Team ‚Äì you‚Äôve been very helpful.  
Hope to see you soon.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Used the e consult form and actioned within 12‚Ä¶
body: Completed an e-consult form late evening and was contacted by the GP the following day, late morning followed by a home visit 3 hours later. Absolutely amazing and put my mind at rest and referral made.

author: Radiographyvisit2
title: Mammogram at Radiography
body: I had a mammogram first thing in the morning on 11th June 2020. The nurse who did it had a lovely manner and made the process less awkward and uncomfortable.

author: Loobs
title: Nothing offered to patients
body: Referred here by GP after discovery of lump in breast (during corona virus lockdown). Shielding for my husband and to some extent myself (diabetes) so was a reluctant to go to Glasgow as was fairly sure would be something minor. Had a truly awful experience. Staff are very well protected with PPE but absolutely nothing offered to patients - no hand gel, no opportunity for handwashing, no face mask and no indication that staff were even changing gloves between patients - didn't change gloves in consulting room either at start or end of consultation, which would have been reassuring. To top it all, examination took about 60 seconds, told me the breast tissue was normal and the same on both sides, despite there being a defined lump on one breast that is NOT on the other. No test, no ultrasound, no explanation of what the lump, which appeared out of the blue three weeks ago, was. Don't think they even found it. Wish I hadn't put my husband's life at risk - won't be doing again. Will however make sure that my experience is recorded should anything happen to me.

author: Miss VB
title: Gender identity
body:
After speaking to my GP, and getting a referral to a Gender Identity Clinic, after about 12 months I was invited to a group workshop to talk with other potential patients, former patients, to meet the staff and talk about the process of being referred to the clinic. It was extremely helpful and demystifying for what was a very daunting process.  
I received my first appointment soon after and has various appointments with different professionals over the course of 12 months who assessed me. It was just like having a chat and I felt incredibly comfortable with the process and the team. A case conference was held in my absence and I received a diagnosis of gender dysphoria and transsexualism and I was offered treatments. I also received counselling from a mental health nurse, voice coaching and laser hair removal. 2 years on HRT I am now awaiting consideration for surgery. Everyone has been lovely with me, given me extra support when I have needed it, and I feel I am in safe hands.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Kazo
title: My journey
body:
March 2019 I was at a point of not knowing which way to turn. I was grieving for my mum, being bullied at work, dealing with a broken marriage and dealing with ghosts from my past. I decided I needed help. I found the courage to make the call, for counselling. The best decision I ever made. I had my referral call and assessment then there was a wait. October 19 I had my first session with Monica. I didn't know how I would be in the room. Once I was in there my heart just opened and everything poured out. First time ever I could tell someone and know I wasn't being judged, I was being listened too. I came out like a weight had been lifted. From that point I had weekly sessions, some counselling and others E M D R therapy. 21 weeks on and I am ready to leave counselling and put into practice all that I have learnt. The best thing I ever done and I would recommend others to do it.  
I always thought counselling was for mad people. It's NOT! it's for everyone who needs that bit of help.

author: ChesterandWeazel
title: Unprofessional attitude towards other staff
body: I attended A&E at Lincoln County Hospital late in the evening with an injured elbow. The receptionist & most of the other staff were very polite, courteous & helpful. Having had my initial assessment I waited for a doctor to see me. Eventually a doctor came called my name & look me from the reception area to a cubical. On entering the cubical there was a used blue gown which was picked up & then thrown back on the chair. I was then asked to sit on a computer chair & asked what the problem was. At no time did they make any attempt to sanitise their hands after having touched the used gown. I was asked some questions, & told I should have an X-ray. While doing this, another member of staff informed the doctor that I should not have been taken into this cubical & it was designated for usage. The body gesture & attitude in reply was very negative in that they did not verbally acknowledge the staff member, ignoring them and pointing me towards another cubical.Later having had the X-ray, the receptionist called me forward telling me that I had to attend the fracture clinic later that day. The receptionist asked if I had received my medication & had the doctor seen me to which I replied ‚ÄúNo‚Äù. So the receptionist kindly went to locate the doctor to get the information that the doctor should have done. During my stay there was 19 individuals that were registered with the initial waiting time of 35 minutes. When I saw the doctor the numbers had increased up to 33, with the waiting time increased to just over an hour. Never the less, I feel that the Doctor hadn‚Äôt cause to act disrespectful towards other staff members. You're all doing marvellous job & have the highest amount of pride & appreciation for you all. üëçüëç

author: kmcd1966
title: Helpful and professional
body: I had both ultrasound and CT scans today and found the staff to be very helpful and very professional. Its hard for the nurses etc with covid 19 but they went out of there way to help. Well done all in both departments.

title: Did not receive a hot meal
body: My father has been in Woodpecker ward. He was not given any lunch and I was promised that he would receive something to eat and receive a hot meal in the evening. He did not receive a hot meal in the evening, he was given a salad which gave him a bad stomach.

readBy.name: Great Western Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Ms C
title: The level of care my son received
body: I took my 6 year old son to out of hours at Douglas Street at midnight on Thursday evening, I was dealt with by Dr Tolan whose manner, caring attitude and kindness made me feel very comfortable and put my mind at ease regarding my son, this doctor went above and beyond in his role as a doctor.

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

title: Amazing paramedics!!
body: I‚Äôm so great full for the help I received, the two people who helped we were so kind and really reassured me! Honestly two lovely people and on a Friday night they must of been knackered yet they never stopped smiling and once at the hospital they made me comfortable and got me seen to straight away! I would love to personally thank them!

author: thankyou1707
title: Hospital stay
body: When I arrived I was seen very quickly. I was seen by a lovely nurse who was shocked at how high my temperature was. Really reassuring and helped me. Some blood was spilled on my joggers but they were so apologetic. I was then put into a bed and from then on I feel like things just went downhill. When I was admitted nobody offered me any clothes to wear and they could see I had loads of blood on my joggers, I also don‚Äôt think the food was very nice neither and that‚Äôs what made me want to discharge myself because I was so hungry I just couldn‚Äôt stay another 24 hours. I was very upset at one point when I got told I had to stay an extra 24 hours and a lovely nurse came over and helped me calm down and said they would try sort some things out for me. I‚Äôm not sure what the staff member's name was but I was on MEAU B side. This nurse was amazing and so kind to me.

title: Great staff
body: I visited A&E this evening and was very happy with how I was treated went in with a abses mouth swollen the reception are really nice and the 2 narses that seen me very professional polite and didn't have to wait very long at all definitely would recommend this hospital üôÇ

readBy.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

author: BMJpatient
title: A&E eye care
body:
I attended the emergency department on the night of the 12th June 2020 after having something in my eye for a while and my GP told me to go. I'm super anxious, especially with doctors, and this was my first time as a hospital patient.  
I'd like a message passed on because the reception staff, the junior doctor and the senior doctor who saw me in the eye room, as well as the nurse at triage were amazing. So kind, friendly and professional. I felt completely at ease, even with someone poking in my eye! I don't know their names but I hope this reaches them. They're doing an amazing job in such stressful circumstances. I can't thank them enough.

title: Reassurance and Compassion When Needed Most
body:
First thing Friday morning I fell down the stairs, dislocated and fractured my ankle in two places.
From start to finish, the staff were commendable! The nurses and doctors in Resus made me feel calm and at ease when they first did xrays and manipulated it. When I found out I‚Äôd have to face a hospital stay and surgery for the first time without any family members, I was scared and upset. The staff did their utmost to comfort me and to address any worries or fears I may have had. To the nurses who held my hand when I was crying and terrified of my op, to the physiotherapists who help me to get back on my good food so quickly (with the help of some crutches!), to the team on ward 228 who were there day and night whatever I needed! As an independent 24-year-old, needing assistance with getting dressed, washing and even wiping my bottom felt embarrassing but I was put at ease very quickly and nothing was too much trouble! I was treated with such compassion and genuine care, I wish I could thank you all a million times over.
From the bottom of my heart, thank you for making such a scary time a lot less daunting!

readBy.name: University Hospitals of North Midlands NHS Trust

title: Excellent staff
body:
I have attended Global quite a few times in the last 2 years. I can honestly say that the staff are always friendly and professional. I have had quick appointment times and have never had a problem booking a convenient appointment or getting thru on the telephone.
They have been amazing during this pandemic and have adhered to all the requirements for making patients feel safe whilst being one of the only places still operating these procedures relieving some of the pressure on the N&N for sure. 
 I am very grateful for the friendly professional team at Global who have aided me with both private and NHS treatments. The new building looks amazing too! It has always had a calm and welcoming atmosphere.
So Thank You Global for all your help during this pandemic to help me get a proper diagnosis!

title: Well organised and good  practice
body:
I have been a patient here for many years and couldn't speak more highly of the practice and staff. I have always found the service professional and caring. Although it may be frustrating to some who will always want to be seen immediately, I have always been able to get a suitable appointment time. It's important to realise that the online service is available to book appointments and not simply rely on phoning. 
This on line system is really quick and efficient and the practice are merely moving with the times.
They are doing what they should - providing respectful, professional care.

title: Great, quick professional help
body: I have been a member of Brocklebank Group Practice for 12 years now and they are unwavering in their high standard of medical practice. They have dedicated, professional doctors and staff, that work extremely hard for the wellbeing of the patients. I have never battled to get an appointment and feel like they are responsive and helpful. The doctorlink app is brilliant. I logged a a query over the weekend and was phoned at 8:50am on the Monday morning for a telephone video consultation. Quick, reassuring and professional. Great Practice.

title: Best service
body: I had a titanium mesh cheekbone and eye repair and cannot speak too highly of all the team who took such wonderful care of me. They were patient with all my questions and helpful in every possible way. I felt totally safe in their hands. I was lucky to end up in their care after my accident in Australia in January as time had made the repair more difficult.

title: Disappointed in staff member
body:
Today i wanted to request a dr's call back or an appointment after 4pm but due to covid i was told by a member of staff i have to go on website and book on e consultation but when i looked for this section it was nowhere to be found. I rang back doctors spoke with a different member of staff who told me the same as the first member so i said I'd try again. I tried again without success so i rang a 3rd time and the 1st member of staff i had originally spoke with answered again, i was very apologetic and explained i just could not find this e consultation section  so the staff member guided me through but it still did not come up on screen, mine was completely different compared to what the staff member had in front of her. She then explained the website should have a purple logo on top and she read out completely different sections. So then she said.... you must be on the other website?  I replied..... i only knew of one which is patient access.... so i said i would go and look at this other site, also i explained I'm not technical. Then said Goodbye!
When she put phone down it was not completely down and i heard the member of staff rudely discussing me saying how can you find a website so hard to find?, it was clear she was a bit peeved from our telephone conversation there was a few other things she said but it was muffled because i could hear the other member of staff laughing with her‚Å∏. This may seem petty to leave as a review but my point is now i feel extremely uncomfortable ringing back for help with the website and i really do need to speak or see a dr as I'm  in severe pain with my leg. But also its really unprofessional and I'm sure she will feel like me when she sees this review e.g annoyed!  I never have a bad word for st Hillary's but the member of staff in question needs to make sure her phone is down or better still just have some patience with patients, were not all techno.

title: Very confusing
body: It takes for ages to see the right person or even just to speak to them over the phone (and no this is NOT due to covid 19, it's usually like this) and then when you finally get to speak to who you need to they just confuse you so then you end up wondering what to do about your illnesses as you have either very little or no help

title: EMG
body: I had an appointment in the EMG (neurophysiology) department in January. This is my third time of being there. It was a very unpleasant experience and I still feel terribly upset about it. Unfortunately the doctor feels my problems are psychological and told me off for big there again. I went there on the advice of my vascular doctor and find my GP. I have had extensive vascular surgery in another hospital and the doctor wanted to clarify whether I had peripheral nerve compression. I do not think it is up to this doctor or his nurse to make judgements about me or to treat me unpleasantly. Please feel free to share my name with the doctor in question and I am happy to supply the operating notes from my vascular surgery which showed severe compression of both arteries and nerves in my chest.Difficult enough to have gone through all of this over the past few years without being judged. Note: if there is visible wastage in the hand then clearly there is a problem and it can‚Äôt be psychological.,

title: Great doctors and nurses, very rude receptionists
body: I have been coming to this surgery for many years and have always found the doctors and nurses extremely helpful, understanding and supportive.  Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for most of the receptionists (not all).  Often met with rude and abrupt responses from them and it doesn't seem to get looked into.  Some customer service training wouldn't go amiss here!

title: Fantastic Care
body: I would like to thank the maternity services of this hospital. Especially the midwife who was with me throughout the day of my labour and then the midwife who delivered my daughter. I was treated very well by both and the care was fantastic and professional. I am very thankful for these amazing people.

author: Natyc68
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I feel like a person again
body: I found the service absolutely wonderful. I feel like a person again. My therapist I found very comforting and very helpful. At first we worked on setting goals but we soon realised that I wouldn't be able to achieve them at the moment due to the COVID-19 but that didn't affect the service I received. I felt she was very easy to talk to especially over the phone (which I preferred rather than face to face) being in the comfort of my own home and having a chat this gave me peace of mind. Thank you.

title: Outstanding care and support
body: During this difficult time due to coronavirus I would like to comment on the outstanding service the Doctor‚Äôs House Surgery is providing for its patient‚Äôs especially for the vulnerable elderly like my mother. Fantastic reception staff who are extremely helpful who always show care and compassion when you speak to them over the phone. Due to the lockdown, patients are called via video call which I think is wonderful because it make‚Äôs the patient feel connected to their GP, especially if they are elderly like my mother. Her medication is accessed and any adjustments are needed are made. It‚Äôs a sense of security and the Doctor‚Äôs House Surgery provides this. My mother‚Äôs GP is a very wonderful doctor, taking care of her patients needs and addressing to her concerns and looking after her overall wellbeing. Thank you for the fantastic service and Thank you NHS for the kind and compassionate and wonderful Doctor.

author: New mum in a pandemic
title: Forever Grateful
body:
My care from this team and the community midwives has been exceptional. At the start of the pandemic my partner and myself were very worried how things were going to go for us and to be able to enjoy our last pregnancy.  
From meeting my community midwife Kirstie who put me completely at ease and told me every part of the process and took care of all my pregnancy care to make sure I was well and felt comfortable with all that was going on at every appointment. Then when the actual time came for me to give birth after a false start a few days earlier (which was also made very comfortable and put at ease). I went to the hospital to be met with Priscilla who delivered my last baby so knew even though I was only 3cm dilated I should not go home to carry on my labour there so kept me and my partner at the hospital because she knew how quick my baby would come.  
The care and attention we both received from her and the rest of the team was outstanding and I am forever grateful to all of them. I would not of been able to do it without them. So my partner and myself would like to thank them from the bottom of our hearts for everything they did for us and we will be sad that we don‚Äôt get to experience it again but they made our last time the best ever

title: Trying to get results of xray
body:
Having gone to Barnet hospital for an xray and found that no staff were wearing gloves or masks. I rang the surgery to obtain the results but have been on the phone for over one hour. Still could speak to anyone. I have emailed the surgery and await the out come.  
In February I tried for an appointment with the surgery but it proved difficult to get an answer on the phone. This went on for three days. In the end I had to fly abroad for treatment. 
There is not enough doctors or staff at the surgery. In addition the population of Borehamwood is growing and not enough GP's.

author: Piper Fred
title: Treatment of a broken ankle
body: In February I broke an ankle after meeting up with friends. The treatment I received from the staff at Forth Valley Royal Hospital was excellent. The Accident and Emergency staff, radiographer, porters and even the security staff on duty that night were brilliant, and I could not have asked for any better care in the follow up.

author: Granj
title: Rushed to hospital
body: I was rushed to hospital with a very high temperature after passing out at home. The ambulance people were very reassuring and i was taken to the covid ward for assessment and thankfully it was not what i had but a raging infection. The staff in that ward also the other ward I was transferred to were very kind and reassuring also doctors.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Great Practice
body: I was so impressed with the way the practice has managed different ways of working. I submitted an eConsult and was booked a telephone consultation within 48 hours, when previously I would have booked a same day appointment (which meant taking time off work). The doctor was able to review my psoriasis and prescribe me cream by looking at the photos I submitted. The prescription was sent to my chemist so I didn't even need to attend the practice! Will definitely use eConsult again in the near future. Well done Speedwell.

author: Ningle
title: Emergency care
body:
I recently dislocated my knee replacement and was brought by a wonderful ambulance team to NWP casualty.  
I would just like to say that the care I had from Dr‚Äôs, nurses care assistants, porters and radiographers and ward staff on Evelyn ward was professional, kind sympathetic and in fact superb .  
I would like to commend you all. Thank you

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust
East Of England Ambulance Service NHS Trust

author: Stan1988ncfc
title: Good care throughout
body: Received surgery at the Day Case Unit, Boston Pilgrim Hospital. Good care throughout.

title: Extremely rude staff
body: Reception staff shouting at my mother. My mother's fault because she can't speak English well. Practice Manager walking around at the back, saw this and ignored. I didn't make official complaint because they all looking out for their staff. Noone believe us people from abroad

title: Great new receptionist finally!
body:
I was previously with this surgery until I had enough of the old staff at front desk. I moved to Wharf Practice but just my luck they merged!
To my surprise today I spoke to a new receptionist. I couldn't believe how incredibly pleasant she was. As I'm used to non professional people there. She had manners and was very caring and attentive. Please please keep her! For the first time in a very long time I've hung up with a smile on my face. Thank you to that very sweet caring lady.

title: Excellent care and kindness
body:
I have had 1 outpatient procedure, a visit to A&E and a ward stay over during this month. 
I witnessed such patience, understanding and humanity shown to an elderly dementia patient whilst on Rayne Ward.
I am so grateful for the wonderful care and kindness I have received from the Gynaecology staff. The response time following my GP referral was speedy too. Thank you Broomfield.

title: Incompetent practice
body:
A very bad experience. The doctor numerously cut me off mid-sentence every time I tried to explain my situation and circumstances, failing to listen to my reasoning, and jumping to his own conclusions, leading to a rash decision to harshly terminate my use of Dexamfetamine. I explained the benefits and improvements in which the medication had provided, but he disregarded that.
The clinic has not telephoned me to check up on my wellbeing, since forcing me the medication in October 2019, contrary to making it very clear to the clinic and my GP on many occasions that I have been struggling with ADHD symptoms for the past eight months.
After reading their Care Plan report, I was shocked by the fact that the nurse had provided false information. Additionally, taking my words out of context. Due to my frustration, which led to depression, as a result of a lack of productivity, due to the absence of ADHD medication, I was left with no choice but to file a complain against Maudsley Hospital‚Äôs ADHD clinic on 21 January 2020.
I received a response from the Complaint‚Äôs department on 10 March 2020, stating the adverse effects of the medication I was taking was ‚Äòsevere‚Äô. This was completely false, as on the contrary, I provided several facts to the doctor, describing the benefits of being the medication; not only improvements in my productivity, but positive life changes due to a good mental wellbeing, and enhanced motivation.
Further to appealing the complain in March 2020, I have yet to receive a response from the sender of the letter. 
After liaising with my GP, the doctor wrote another referral letter to the clinic, explaining how my ADHD symptoms had worsened over the course of eight months without medication, affecting my personal life and professional aspirations. 

I received a telephone call from the nurse, a couple of weeks ago, who stated that the doctor was absent from his duties at the clinic.
It is to my knowledge that NHS doctors are working virtually. Therefore, I do not understand why the doctor at the ADHD clinic, is NOT working virtually.

author: Musky
title: Eye Department Visit
body:
I visited the Eye Department for my regular Eye Injection today 15th June 2020 I was 15 minutes early for my appointment, I was still out in 30 minutes. Fantastic.  
This was at the new clinic by the Mottistone Suite.  
I have been coming for 17 years now for various injections in my eye, Always good and friendly at St Marys, Isle of Wight.  
I have been to a few eye departments and have friends that go to eye departments on the mainland. The Isle of Wight is to my opinion the best one going.  
Keep up the good work.  
Just one observation. The signage at the new suit is very misleading, and there was no one on reception at the new unit.

title: great practice
body: The doctor is brilliant doctor.Everytime he has provide excellent service and always always look after his patients well being in depth

title: Poor Administration
body: Told to telephoned for an appointment at 8.30 am , line engaged for 20 minutes -then all appointments booked.  Same in the afternoon at 1.30 pm and the following morning.  Staff totally indifferent and was told "that's just how it is".  No attempt to consider ways of improving the service.

author: Madge51
title: Attending outpatient clinic
body:
It might be helpful for staff to establish whether people attending clinic have been SHIELDING as opposed to self isolating. I got the distinct impression that I was seen as a potential risk to them when in fact they represented a huge risk to me.  
I left hospital after surgery on Jan 30th & have only left my home twice since then. On both occasions it was to attend the Orthopedic clinic.  
To reduce the anxiety of venturing out after such s long time shielding, I would have appreciated being seen at the appointed time. That didn't happen & I was very uneasy as more people came through the area & didn't feel able to wait an indeterminate period of time & potentially be exposed to asymptomatic people in a confined space.

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: RJED
title: Gave us privacy
body:
Last year I unfortunately lost my daughter to stillbirth from pre eclampsia.The staff at the maternity unit were nothing short of amazing. They dealt with me and my partner sensitively, and we could tell that they really cared about our wellbeing, and had our best interests at heart.  
They went above and beyond to make our stay as comfortable as possible, even going as far to move us to another room on the ward, which was more quiet and and gave us more privacy to grieve.  
Big thank you to all staff on the maternity unit- you not only saved my life, but made our stay with you a little bit easier during what was a very difficult time.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Hmmmh
title: A good place to get better
body:
The staff here are ok, they are all very different but each in a good way. You have some that say they are ‚Äúfirm to be kind‚Äù others that are strict but in a good way. Each to their own.  
It does get frustrating, but you know the staff are here to listen.  
They do care! They will fight for you even when you don‚Äôt realise it.  
They do things for your benefit even if you don‚Äôt like it, or agree with it. You can have a laugh with the nurses and the HCA‚ÄôS. The new Activity‚Äôs coordinator is great, has been here a while but just changed job roles.  
The doctors here are ok, change quite a lot.  
SALTS Person is very helpful, and really kind, you know they are listening.  
The OT and APIP People are great. It‚Äôs fun going in the garden and painting with them.  
I feel like here is a good place to get better, it just comes with a lot. Especially when you haven‚Äôt been in hospital before. It‚Äôs terrifying.  
This ward I‚Äôm on isn‚Äôt that bad, the staff make it so much better. And without them I personally know I‚Äôd be a lot worse

author: Balvicar mum
title: Consistent care and support
body:
I gave birth to my second son two weeks ago today. It could have been a daunting experience, given all the choas which has ensued during lockdown, and the restrictions on service delivery. However, my experience was the opposite. Despite reduced staffing, the Oban midwifery team managed continuing care throughout my pregnancy, meaning we got consistent care and support from our midwife and we were supported to plan our home birth, which wouldn't have been possible in a city area.  
We had a wonderful experience and i cannot speak highly enough of the team in Oban.

title: Really unsympathetic and on occasions outright‚Ä¶
body: My mother committed suicide when I was 5 and I have suffered with insomnia since then.  Although there were periods of respite. Insomnia have now become constant.  I have gone weeks and weeks without sleep. Three medical consultants through 111 phoned me and suggested that I read, that I write and were not helpful. It became so bad that I called MIND.  I explained a little of my history and she concurred The Simpson Centre had at the very least been unhelpful.  Several Doctors were actually rude. They would not help me with my sleep problem and didn't agree that the sleep medication they prescribed me were insufficient.  This medication did not allow me to sleep. One argued that I didn't need LEVOTHYROXINE 50 MCG. Some years ago (when I was living in the USA - I lost over 30 lbs and my MD put my inhospitable. Diagnosis over or under active thyroid gland. Two years ago a small cancer module was found on my lung. I also have PTSD and Severe Social Anxiety.  The Doctors at The Simpson Centre were not in the least bit interested

author: Bee54
title: Made my stay as comfortable as possible
body:
I recently spent 7 days in hospital within ward 2b, I would just like to thank the staff for taking such great care of me despite the virus they went above and beyond to make my stay as comfortable as possible. I suffer with my mental health and they could not have been more empathetic and understanding about this too.  
Special thank you to nurse Erin, she is amazing at what she does and helped me so much throughout my stay.  
Thanks ward 2b :)

title: made to feel worthless
body: My community nurse left..Replacement appulling.Couldn't care if i lived or died made it known twice when I've spoken to them they are busy.I have been completely abandoned by chippenham mental heath team during this crisis the mentle health nurse that is my previous nurses replacement has actually made me ill and after talking to them I've had to place a call to the Samaritans..I will never come forward and except any help from these people again...

title: Absolutely fantastic
body: I had a really good experience with the therapist and would definitely recommend anybody to go for it

readBy.name: Midlands Partnership NHS Foundation Trust o

title: Great department
body: After having undertaken an operation for reconstructive hand surgery just before Christmas I would just like to say how fantastically well I was treated by ALL  the staff and departments involved from the first day I attended to been signed off 6 months later. Special thanks to the after care team in hand therapy you were brilliant.

title: Fantastic practice
body: I have had a double lung transplant and when I need things sorted out bye the GP the Starff are very helpful all the time many thanks

title: Excellent receptionists!
body: I ordered my repeat medication today and within a short while was sent a text to say it was ready, when I rang to pay for my script the receptionist was delightful and really really helpful. I know you are all so so under pressure at the moment and I absolutely take my hat off to you all! Thank you.

title: Great caring practice
body: I did a e consultation yesterday afternoon for a problem I had doctor responded by 9.30am next morning with a nice email and a prescription to deal with my problem. Excellent service from the practice as normal and in the difficult situation we are all in at present with covid.i have been at this practice for 30 years would not ever change fantastic doctors and staff.thankyou

title: Great Service
body: I was very grateful to the receptionist for arranging a blood test for me during these difficult times. She managed to find out the blood test I needed and arrange it for me. Arriving for my blood test, I was seen within 5 minutes of my arrival and was dealt with by a very nice gentleman who made me feel at ease. Thank you very much.

title: Appalling lack of care and communication
body:
They transferred my mum into this home from hospital  and the care may be good but there was no communication with me her daughter at all from the home , the nurses or the consultant even though they had my number on record 
Phones calls are not answered and when I got through a nurse told me she was doing ok ! She would get a social worker to ring me They didn‚Äôt and I had no other communication until I was told they were sending my mum, a frail old lady with a urine infection who is in bed all the time , home this week on her own , and they couldn‚Äôt even tell me what care package has been put in place !! Appalling

title: Communication and understanding
body: My husband is Deaf - signs British sign language. The security lady was so helpful and determined to make sure that my husband had access and communication - she made sure I was admitted into the restricted area too. Thank you v much for your humanity and awareness. The nurse on the door wasn‚Äôt Deaf aware (but security sorted it). Thank you to the caring and efficient male nurse who saw my husband at the final station in A&E and the X-Ray people - thank you for your Deaf awareness re how are deaf ppl supposed to see through masks? And thank you to the kind and efficient gentlemen in the waiting area of the x-ray department. We may have waited 3 long hours but your Deaf awareness and professionalism was appreciated.

readBy.name: The Hillingdon Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Great service and care
body:
It was my first experience of Clifton park . The care, attention and service I received during my appointment was exceptional. All the staff involved in my care were excellent. Some of the staff doing new roles because of covid-19 . Everybody involved in my care were so attentive during these strange times we find ourselves in. I was treated with the upmost care and respect and They were all so polite, friendly And easy to talk to. I felt at ease and completely relaxed and comfortable during my day there . 
I can not fault the staff, hospital or service I received during my surgery and care . 
The staff explained how thing we‚Äôre going to happen and why during these strange time and new procedures because of  covid-19 . 
It was my first experience of treatment at Clifton Park Hospital and would definitely recommend it for the hospital, staff , care and service I received and would score it all as 10/10 , 5***** top rated hospital , staff and facility.
Theatre staff would just as highly recommended and rated . Great care all round . 
I can not THANKYOU enough .

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Rapid response to request / problem rectification
body:
Had problem with prescription renewal. Sent message via new website. Got delivery from Boots Banstead in less than an hour. Fantastic! The speed of response is better than Amazon Prime 
Much appreciated JB : - )

title: Bad recieptionist
body: Rang up at 8 o'clock this morning asked if was possible to see a doctor got told they were doing phone consultations only so gave them my details and got told i'd get a phone call later at 4 o'clock I rang to see why nobody had rung only to be told that nobody had been in my file to book one this is not acceptable thank you to the one I spoke to at 4 because she's rung back to make sure she'd got my details

title: Lousy Communication
body: Although I appreciate that there are extra pressures due to coronavirus, I think it unreasonable to have to wait for more than several weeks with no response/acknowledgement to my queries regarding errors (not the first time) on my medical records, or when asked by a receptionist to drop a communication by from a Consultant with regard to a referral (for the GP to look at), and my finding someone at short notice to drop it by as I am disabled, then hearing nothing again?! This lack of response/poor communication has been going on for several years, and it is getting worse.... a family member belongs to another local practice and they get back to emails, letters, online requests normally within 24 hours and often within a few hours (text, email and phone), so why can't Fitzalan Medical Centre do the same??

title: Helpful Doctors BUT Rude Receptionists
body:
The receptionist does not know how to treat or talk to patients. They are very inconsiderate of what the patient may be going through. 
The doctors are helpful, once I am able to get through to them.

title: Telephone consultation and response excellent
body: I was made an appointment to see a Rectal colon specialist and advised it would be over the phone. When the call didn't come I rang up and was advised that the Doctor had rung but hadn't got a reply. Unfortunately the note on the file about which number to use hadn't been highlighted. I was advised to speak to the medical secretary which I did the next morning and she spoke to the consultant explaining and he rang me that afternoon. He was very very nice over the phone and I sensed that he was really listening even though we couldn't see each other. Within 10 days I was seen for an investigation at the hospital and await another investigation in 2 weeks.  I was very grateful that medical secretary sorted out the issue over the call and that it didn't delay my care. Well done WHH

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Worst place ever useless and rude staff
body: I have been trying to get seen for weeks and getting fobbed off in regards to my newborn they dont want to prescribe anything and the symptoms are getting worse I've had to buy everything myself spending a fortune on items they could prescribe me. 6 week check was abysmal I wasn't checked at all..and given wrong information even a chemist advised against.

title: Compassion at its finest
body: We can never repay the care and compassion shown to my dad and our family when he passed aaay peacefully on Malins Ward. The staff were so kind, caring and sensitive and made a very difficult situation something very special. I cant thank you all enough for your dedication, compassion and care

title: Great video call consultation
body: Really appreciated my video call consultation today . The doctor rang twice because I missed first call . Great manner and information given .

title: Caring team working in Urgent Care
body: They are an amazing team and very caring. I was treated quickly in a friendly professional manner. Thank you for your care. I am proud to have Kings as my local hospital. Thank you

readBy.name: King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent service on two occasions
body:
I had to call the Ambulance Service on two separate occasions recently, 30th May and 9th June. Both times, the Paramedics were professional, kind and made full assessments of my husband‚Äôs condition. He had to be admitted to hospital for emergency treatment and on the second occasion, an operation for a serious condition.
Thank you for being so considerate and dealing with the situation so well, Thankfully he is now recovering.

title: Helpful but judgemental service experience
body: I was referred to Gravesham minor injuries by the 111 service recently. I attended Gravesham minor injuries to be told that I could not be seen there, was incorrectly told I was contagious for chicken pox and was quickly removed from the minor injuries waiting room.  I was directed towards the primary care unit and told to call 111 again and see if the doctor attending could fit me in as I needed assessment and anti viral medication for shingles.  I was told to sit in the waiting area in the phlebotomy/primary care area by a staff member. When the doctor called me in, they told me I should not be there and should not have been in the waiting area in case someone pregnant was there.  Shingles is only contagious for chicken pox during the blister phase and I barely had skin redness in my armpit (the area of which was completely covered by my clothes). I was made to feel guilty about not having a clinician‚Äôs level of understanding regarding the risk I ‚Äòmight‚Äô pose and only did as I was told by medical staff.  I was made to feel like I could have made someone else ill and was wasting the doctor‚Äôs time, despite following the instructions I was given by health professionals and effective treatment being time dependant from the onset of symptoms.  I was feeling very unwell and I would not want anyone else to be made to feel the same way I did with the ‚Äòcare‚Äô I received. I am thankful to the doctor for managing to fit me in quickly and prescribing me the anti virals that appear to have halted the progression of the shingles and I am feeling better now but improvements in patient care could be made.

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Couldn't Be Better
body:
I was taken by ambulance to A&E on Sunday 24th May 2020.  I was treated first of all by a very pleasant triage nurse who settled me onto a bed and took some details.  He looked at my arm which I had hurt when I fell that afternoon.  He then sent me to X-ray, where the staff were kind but firm as I had to hold my arm in painful positions for the x-rays.

It transpired that I had dislocated my elbow and after two failed attempts by two doctors to relocate it, another doctor was called and on the third attempt by three doctors, my elbow snapped back into place.

I then was told I could go home and a lovely porter came to take me in a wheelchair to the exit where I met my cab.

I must just mention the nurse who put a cannula in my hand in Resus.  She too was lovely and the only professional ever to put a needle in a vein in my hand or anywhere else, for it to come out without leaving a mark, and certainly not the usual huge bruise.  Well done!

Thank you so much to all who helped and treated me that day.  I am grateful for your professionalism, dedication and skill.  Also, your kindness, which you can't learn and you showed it naturally.  Kindness and compassion for a suffering fellow human being.  What more could be asked for?

title: Total knee replacement
body: I had a TKR on 1st February and stayed in hospital for 1 night. The surgeon and team were marvelous. The aftercare including nursing, advice and physio were wonderful. I came home and took paracetamol for 2 days and have made a wonderfull recovery. Can't thank them enough.

readBy.name: North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: Wolfie1
title: Occupational Health referral
body:
I was recently referred by Primary Care to work with Claire, an Occupational Therapist based through Barns Medical Practice in Ayr.  
Claire worked with me to develop my self management skills in relation to ongoing mental health issues related to my physical health and social anxiety due to ongoing health problems I suffer from.  
I found the services provided by Claire greatly helped me, in particular to manage a recently difficult period I had been struggling with.  
I felt that the support Claire offered throughout the sessions by listening, guiding and offering advice suited to me, along with working through the workbook exercises, helped me to focus and regain the drive I have needed for a long time.  
She also offered me information in local key services i.e local yoga classes.  
Having completed my work with Claire I feel it important to stress on how important I feel the help and advice she provided is recognised and I really hope that these kind of services continue to be offered by local services.  
It has helped myself through a time where I feel that the things I worked with her on helped me so much more than I could have and probably would not have, managed on my own at the time and I am so grateful that I was able to have had the chance to work with her.

author: Thyrgo
title: Cancelled appointment without notice
body:
Just over a week ago, my dad received a phone call from Manchester Eye Hospital with an appointment for this afternoon. This followed a previous appointment, where the scan taken was blurred. He was expecting a look inside his eye, probably followed by laser treatment to clear his vision.  
I agreed to drive him there, (dad sitting in the far corner of the back seat) although we do not live in the same household, because I did not want someone in their 80‚Äôs to use public transport, which is how he usually goes to appointments.  
Dad arrived for his appointment and was told that the appointment was cancelled yesterday. He had not received either a phone call or text message telling him this.  
Although his records were not available, the staff looked on the computer, and repeated the tests carried out previously. They explained briefly how the laser works, as my dad is nervous about treatments. However, they confirmed that the laser was not operational at the moment.  
Questions:  
1. Why was the appointment, only made a week ago, cancelled, and why was my dad not told? Was it because the laser wasn‚Äôt working, or something else?  
2. With the current COVID-19 situation, why was my dad put at risk? Travel, passing other people in the hospital, seeing staff unnecessarily.  
I am extremely unhappy that an elderly vulnerable adult was put in this situation.

author: Glad867
title: Some recommendations
body:
After a successful 4 years at Wathwood I would like to thank the responsible authorities and make these recommendations:  
1. Hobbies and fairs every 6 months to encourage outside interests.  
2. Shared patient canteen for better interaction.  
3. Room time out provision for productive management.  
4. Access to social internet space.  
5. Separate coffee bar.  
  
Therapy sessions have been worthwhile and education has provided some self development.  
  
Minimum medication intervention has contributed to least restrictive practice and management has been based on trust.  
  
I would only request that touches are less invasive and fitted with filters, and at some point shower cubicles are replaced with wet rooms.  
  
Overall a productive experience and one which I would recommend.

title: Amazing GP!
body: Been to 3 practises in my area of Dagenham and Oval road is BY FAR the best I have been to. Doctor & Nurse always take concerns seriously and do anything they can to ease your mind & find a solution. Lovely, Polite staff, including the receptionist. Thank you all, I‚Äôm grateful to have you.

author: Sd8344
title: My daughter's recurring UTI
body: My 4 year old daughter has been suffering with recurring UTI‚Äôs since the last week in April. We have visited Glasgow sick children‚Äôs a& e 3 times, Paisley out of hours 3 times and I have spoken with my GP at least twice a week. She has been given 6 different antibiotics but they did not seem to be having any effect. In mid June after finishing a 12 day course of antibiotics my daughter's condition was deteriorating I called my GP who referred her to The Sick Children's Hospital in Glasgow. She was examined by a doctor who gave us more antibiotics and sent her home after 40 minutes, I questioned why more was not being done for her as the antibiotics were not working! I then called my paediatrician's secretary the next morning who advised she would ask for me to receive a call back. The paediatrician called me the following day advising my daughter should be admitted to hospital for IV antibiotics and an ultrasound of her kidneys and bladder. We were admitted to Glasgow Sick Children‚Äôs Hospital ward 2C. My daughter had a cannula fitted by a trainee advanced nurse practitioner and a student nurse who were very professional and sympathetic towards my very upset daughter, they took their time and spoke us both through what was happening. They then took bloods and administrated IV antibiotics. We did not see a doctor until later that same night who informed me that by my daughters infection markers, the infection seemed to have travelled to her kidneys and she would have to stay in a few days for more IV antibiotics and blood tests to check her infection markers each day - this did not happen.We had a tough few days but most nurses were very helpful but unfortunately there was a minority who it seemed did not want to be there or help anyone. My daughter was examined by a doctor each morning, each doctor had a different opinion on what was happening with my daughter and I am still not clear as to why she is having these recurring UTI‚Äôs or when they will stop. Early the following week, we were spoken to by a doctor who gave us a lot of helpful information on my daughters bladder and how to hopefully prevent anymore infections, and discharged us with a 7 day course of oral antibiotics. After I spoke to the doctor I had asked a nurse if my daughter would have her bloods checked before we would leave to check her infection markers were lowering, the nurse was in my opinion very rude with a very bad attitude - tutted at me and told me that ‚Äúif that was to happen a doctor would have told me‚Äù. The same nurse removed my daughters cannula and was again I feel very rude to me and my daughter, who as you can imagine was very upset, saying she was scared and instead of being sympathetic and helping my daughter this nurse proceeded to shout above my daughter telling her to "stop screaming right now and let me do my job" and she would see that it wasn‚Äôt sore. This only served to make my daughter fearful and her crying intensified. After the cannula was removed the raised voice continued, saying I told you so! I was very upset by the body language and attitude towards both of us and had to leave the hospital right away as I was very shook up and shocked at the whole situation! The scan that I was advised my daughter was to receive was not carried out, and we have been asked to attend the hospital again for the ultrasound to be done.

author: memberdx36
title: Hernia pain
body: I attended A&E with pain from a hernia. The doctor got a nurse in, then I laid on the bed to be examined. They carried out a thorough examination of my groin.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Chariotte
title: Helpful staff at the phlebotomy clinic
body:
Husband needed blood taken and staff at the Phlebotomy clinic at Coatbridge were brilliant. They came out as soon as they could and the young nurse called Kim was great ,put husband at easy,very helpful and freindly. Then after that his bloods needed done again and they phoned me right away ,gave me a date and time and out they came . We would like to thank all the staff at the clinic and a big thank you to Pauline and Kim. We are both sheilding and now he has to get his bloods done on a regular basis he is relieved and happy that a nurse is comming to the house one less problem to deal with.  
[Very happy with 'Nurses']

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: electric chanter
title: Nothing short of exemplary
body:
I was admitted to Station 4 at Ayr Hospital from Crosshouse hospital in the middle of June during the COVID pandemic after being diagnosed with kidney stones.  
Any time that I needed hospital treatment previously it was carried out by the private sector. The only reason for this is that I am covered by work insurance policy.  
I can honestly say that the way in which I was treat in Station 4 was nothing short of exemplary from my arrival to my discharge. Every person with whom I had contact with showed the utmost professionalism and respect anyone could ever ask for. Nothing was a problem for any of them. I certainly appreciate the treatment I received during what was probably the most painful episode I have ever experienced in my lifetime. They made it so much easier to cope with.  
I would like to thank everyone who showed me just how caring and dedicated our people in our NHS are, especially in such terrible times as we find ourselves in today.  
Thank you once again, respect to you all.

author: Bell95
title: Being refused a planned caesarean section
body:
I am currently 21 weeks pregnant with my 2nd child, I was due to have a planned c- section with my first pregnancy due to baby being breach and a low lying placenta. This turned into an emergency caesarean due to a hemorrhage before the birth of my daughter. I had planned on having an elective section with my 2nd child due to the traumatic nature of the first labour.  
I had an over the phone appointment at 17 weeks and was informed that an elective section was only an option if this had been my 3rd pregnancy due to Covid-19. I was told my only option was a VBAC. I was shocked by this information and asked for it in writing ( which I still have not received nearly 5 weeks later.)  
I can not find any information online that this is the case, and I have been informed that this is not happening in England by a midwife there as it would be taking away my rights to a choice of how I labour. I would like someone from Wishaw Hospital to explain if this is the case or if I need to request to talk to someone else.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: suspireandexhale
title: Hysteroscopy - A Positive Experience
body:
I was referred under the urgent 2 week protocol for post menopausal bleeding and when biopsy and transvaginal ultrasound were inconclusive, I was invited to return for a hysteroscopy in the nurse led clinic using only paracetamol for pain relief. I also have vaginal atrophy and to say I was a nervous wreck about the procedure would be an understatement. The hysteroscopist inspired confidence from the beginning and assured me that I could stop the process at any time if I found it too painful.  
Ultimately, I have no idea why I fretted so much. The procedure itself probably only took 5 minutes. Insertion of the hysteroscope was extremely uncomfortable, and although the 2 nurses who were assisting tried to distract me with chatter, I struggled to respond preferring to concentrate on deep breathing. The lead spotted this immediately and assured me that I didn't have to engage. The team was extremely helpful in talking me through every step of the way (helping me to do my best to relax, and even pointing out the "landmarks" that appeared on the screen ). When I hesitated, in panic, at the idea of snipping a polyp that was identified, I felt under no presssure to continue. I consented and can honestly say I didn't feel a thing. Removal of the hysteroscope was very quick after that and only mildly uncomfortable.  
The hysteroscopist spent time talking with me both before and afterwards and willingly answered all my questions.  
I still have the results to come but I left the hospital skipping.

readBy.name: South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Candy56
title: Good communication is vital
body:
My father was admitted at the beginning of June for safeguarding reasons (a whole other story). He is I am told happy and well cared for and I had a call most weekdays asking whether his home was now ready for his return (it is). My unhappiness is that the attempt to return him a week or so later, failed (I believe because the re-ablement team asked that a mental health assessment be done on the ward, 9a) and communications did not happen.  
I was not happy that a 4 hr window for hospital transport was planned but his care worker would not be present until 1755. The nurse I spoke to said this was unavoidable and that the ambulance staff would do their best to liaise with the care agency. I stressed that it was essential he be met and settled to avoid triggering delirium.  
It did not happen. I was not told. I missed a call which I assume was to inform me. However it was from the main switchboard and I had no idea who to ring to find out what was happening and did not get a further call.  
My point is that good communication is vital and not being heard or communicated with as the primary family carer who is shielding is guaranteed to undermine trust and cause emotional distress. I am aware that these are particularly difficult times but comms were of an acceptable standard up to this point. I have not had the promised phone call to update me. This is causing increasing levels of anxiety and distress.

author: Goldberry
title: Ophthalmology needs a liaison nurse / officer
body:
I am a frequent flyer and have had excellent care from all the people that work in Aberdeen's Ophthalmology department, however, I feel there is a crucial role that is missing from the team - a liaison nurse or officer. I need someone that can translate consultant into common tongue, hold my hand, answer my questions, and explain the potential next steps.  
I suffer from a complex uveitis problem, that I don't fully understand even to this day. Luckily it was just active in my left eye until I found out today that it's now also in my right eye. The current medication is no longer holding the problem and quite frankly I'm sitting here crying, unsure what this means for me. So I now have a a very bad left eye and a right eye that's going the same way. What will happen with regards to my job / career, driving, and all the other things that come with potential sight loss, are there any alternatives. I do find it so hard to speak to my consultant at the best of times - please is there a middle person - that can help?

readBy.name: Office of Stewart Stevenson, MSP for Banffshire and Buchan Coast

author: NicS
title: Pain clinic
body:
I got told I I had fibromyalgia June 2017 and I was 32 at the time. By October that year I got sent to the pain clinic and doctor said fibromyalgia was all in my head and used my panic attacks and anxiety as the main cause. Even though I was at the royal and seen the team there so deals with conditions like fibromyalgia and I mostly got it from having a nasty fall on the ice.  
At stobhill they used the mental health card on me. I walked out crying to my friend on the phone and I reported the incident to my own GP who was going to look into it. Having a hidden condition is real and they shouldn‚Äôt be using the mental health card on people.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Really problematic staff, lacking in care.
body:
Really unhappy with my two years at Elmswood. I have had a number of issues, including really poor medical service and incredibly rude admin staff. The surgery doesn't seem to be run with patients in mind at all. 

The appointments with staff have been shambolic for all of my family, with no real resolution to any issues. The admin and reception staff are rude, uncommunicative. They have inexplicably removed the ability to get a prescription over the phone during a pandemic, which would necessitate a trip to the doctors to be signed up to online services during a pandemic and a lock down. I had the phone slammed down on me three times today, (without warning or justification) and experienced the most unprofessional behaviour I think I have ever faced in a medical practice. I worry for the more vulnerable patients, who don't have the strength to assert themselves. 

I have started the process of moving my family elsewhere after today.

author: Kpar3
title: My dad
body: My dad was taken in to GRI with suspected Covid 19 . On the 7th Apr. After it was confirmed that he did have it he was moved to ward 38 . We couldn‚Äôt visit for 10 days but the staff were great ! We phoned every day for an update They told him we were thinking of him every day ! He had dementia so was a very difficult time . When dad became poorly I was allowed to visit just for an hr each day. Sadly dad passed away on the 21st Apr. Thankfully I was with him holding his hand. Thanks to all the staff for caring for him, for the kind words & cups of tea at a very difficult time, especially Dr Deeny! He phoned me with regular updates he was a great support to me through an awful time when other family members couldn‚Äôt be. Myself & my family will be forever grateful.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston
University of Glasgow - School of Medicine, Dentistry and Nursing

author: JAS20
title: Waiting time for son's treatment
body:
We were advised that someone would contact this month, regarding our son's treatment for grommets and adenoid removal.  
We can fully appreciate the strain that the NHS is under, given the current situation with the Coronavirus pandemic but we are eager to find out if and approximately when our son will receive this treatment?  
We look forward to hearing from you,  
Kind regards

title: Great staff, safe, clean and organised
body: I attended A and E Sunday evening due to cutting my hand deeply in a kitchen accident. I was checked in quickly and seen by triage within 15 minutes. Everything was safely done and very clean. I was sent straight for X-ray and again no wait. I was then seen by a doctor who was so friendly and caring. Then again by a nurse who couldn‚Äôt stitch the difficult area so had to get the doctor. He was so calming and kind. As I felt very faint and sick  at the sight of the wound.  I was stitched up and discharged with ease. All staff were so friendly and was organised. Thank you.

author: Parsman
title: I was extremely worried about the surgery
body:
I had left knee revision survey on the Orthopaedic Trauma Ward following removal of infected knee and tissue restoration.  
I was extremely worried about the surgery and concerned about having a successful outcome.  
Throughout my stay at Ninewells Hospital, I was impressed by the professionalism and attitude by all levels of staff, including Consultants, Nurses, Specialists and support staff. This was despite the restrictions and difficulties presented by the COVID-19 pandemic.  
All stages of my treatment plan were explained beforehand and outcomes clearly explained after each step. This was extremely re-assuring to me and I was impressed that all medical staff were up-to-date on the current status throughout. Obviously, internal communication is very efficient.  
On a practical level, nursing staff were happy to cover lack of patient visitors by accommodating delivery of personal supplies and laundry via hospital reception. This was particularly successful after a week or two.  
I was most impressed by the overall care provided.,

title: Efficient, professional and caring!
body:
I was referred to the breast clinic by my doctor a week ago!
I was worried about attending hospital and due to lockdown.
PPE was offered on arrival and  plenty of hand sanitizers available (except 2 empty containers at the exit doors)
The consultant and all the other staff were professional yet caring and the service from consultant to mammogram to scan was completed within a couple of hours within an hour!
Thanks so much üåü

title: excellent practice
body:
when visiting newham medical centre 
You are greeted with total professionalism and an excellent attitude of duty of care to patients from the reception staff and are very helpful and polite and good team work. and the centre waiting area is very clean and tidy and all the doctors are great and I hold a high regard also for the telephone manners when calling and all staff at the surgery are a great asset serving the community and the great reflection of the NHS that provide and very happy with all staff at newham medical centre with the work they do
